intro: Struthanthus triceps, commonly known as the three-fingered broom, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod-like fruits. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and produces bright yellow flowers during the spring and early summer. Its name refers to the three pairs of leaflets on its compound leaves, which resemble fingers. Struthanthus triceps is adapted to arid conditions and has a low, sprawling growth habit.
